entry.et: Middle English, perhaps from Old English *cyllan; akin to Old English cwellan to kill quell

def.dt: :to deprive of life :cause the death of
:to slaughter (as a hog) for food
:to convert a food animal into (a kind of meat) by slaughtering
:to put an end to kill competition
:defeat veto killed the amendment
:to mark for omission
:delete
:annihilate destroy kill an enemy
:to destroy the vital or essential quality of killed the pain with drugs
:to cause to stop kill the motor
:to check the flow of current through
:to make a markedly favorable impression on she killed the audience
:to get through uneventfully kill time
:to get through (the time of a penalty) without being scored on kill a penalty
:to cause extreme pain to
:to tire almost to the point of collapse
:to hit (a shot) so hard in various games that a return is impossible
:to consume (as a drink) totally
:to deprive one of life
:to make a markedly favorable impression was dressed to kill

entry.pt: kill slay murder assassinate dispatch execute mean to deprive of life. kill merely states the fact of death caused by an agency in any manner killed in an accident frost killed the plants. slay is a chiefly literary term implying deliberateness and violence but not necessarily motive slew thousands of the Philistines. murder specifically implies stealth and motive and premeditation and therefore full moral responsibility convicted of murdering a rival. assassinate applies to deliberate killing openly or secretly often for political motives terrorists assassinated the Senator. dispatch stresses quickness and directness in putting to death dispatched the sentry with one bullet. execute stresses putting to death as a legal penalty executed by lethal gas.

def.dt: :an act or instance of killing
:a decisive act that conclusively secures something (as a deal or win)
:something killed: as
:an animal shot in a hunt
:animals killed in a hunt, season, or particular period of time
:an enemy unit (as an airplane or ship) destroyed by military action
:a return shot in any of various games (as badminton, handball, or table tennis) that is too hard for an opponent to handle
:channel creek used chiefly in place names in Delaware, Pennsylvania, and New York
:to destroy in large numbers or totally
hill E North Carolina near village of Kit*ty Hawk ggkill03.wavˈki-tē-ˌhȯk on sand barrier opposite Albemarle Sound
channel between New Jersey & Staten Island, New York, connecting Newark Bay & Upper New York Bay
:to kill (as a plant) by exposure to winter conditions
:to die as a result of exposure to winter conditions

entry.et: Middle English clok, from Middle Dutch clocke bell, clock, from Old French or Medieval Latin; Old French dialect (Picard) cloque bell, from Medieval Latin clocca, of Celtic origin; akin to Middle Irish clocc bell

def.dt: :a device other than a watch for indicating or measuring time commonly by means of hands moving on a dialect
:any periodic system by which time is measured
:a registering device usually with a dialect
:odometer
:time clock
:a synchronizing device (as in a computer) that produces pulses at regular intervals
:biological clock
:with or within a time constraint working against the clock
:with clocked speed rather than the order of finish as the criterion for placement trial races against the clock
:continuously for 24 hours :day and night without cessation
:without relaxation and heedless of time
:to use up as much as possible of the playing time remaining in a game (as football) while retaining possession of the ball or puck especially to protect a lead
:an ornamental figure on the ankle or side of a stocking or sock

entry.et: Middle English; akin to Middle English fitten

def.dt: :adapted to an end or design :suitable by nature or by art
:adapted to the environment so as to be capable of surviving
:acceptable from a particular viewpoint (as of competence or morality) :proper a movie fit for the whole family
:put into a suitable state :made ready get the house fit for company
:being in such a state as to be or seem ready to do or suffer something fair fit to cry I was Bryan MacMahon laughing fit to burst
:sound physically and mentally :healthy
:extremely angry or irritated
:in a striking manner dressed fit to kill

entry.pt: fit suitable meet proper appropriate fitting apt happy, felicitous mean right with respect to some end, need, use, or circumstance. fit stresses adaptability and sometimes special readiness for use or action fit for battle. suitable implies an answering to requirements or demands clothes suitable for camping. meet suggests a just proportioning meet payment. proper suggests a suitability through essential nature or accordance with custom proper acknowledgement. appropriate implies eminent or distinctive fitness an appropriate gift. fitting implies harmony of mood or tone a fitting end. apt connotes a fitness marked by nicety and discrimination apt quotations. happy suggests what is effectively or successfully appropriate a happy choice of words. felicitous suggests an aptness that is opportune, telling, or graceful a felicitous phrase.
